title: Why do they speak Romanian in the movie Borat? - Quora

response.answer_text: Why do they speak Romanian in the movie Borat? As Peter Clings said, it was cheaper and safer to film in Romania (but just in theory because things didn’t go as they planned). They wanted to have a very bad looking place so they went to a Roma majority village, named Glod (the name of the village is an arhaism for “mud”). I’m sure Sasha Cohen was offered the “guest room” but he refused because it didn’t have the “expected” look. I’m sure the Romas there didn’t understand the concept of “fictitious mockumentary”, misunderstandings can get ugly.  (There are 3 villages in Romania called Glod, the chosen one was the closest to București and its international airport. The name has nothing to do with the Roma, only the one closest to București has a Roma majority. And the name of the village has nothing to do with the roads/streets, there’s actually an asphalt main road. The house that was chosen was on purpose the “end of the village” kind, as far as possible from the main road.) I’ve heard that there were some problems with the Romas there, they were paid badly and asked to do stuff like to bring cows inside the house… I’m sure a lot of recorded material fell out at the final cut, I’ve seen the movie only once, but I remember that the people that were supposed to be the main character’s family, were having a bad argument in Romanian actually with Sasha Cohen, not his character, it was totally out of “script” and out of character except for Sasha Cohen, he kept the character. It turns out that he pi**ed them off so bad that it was not that safe anymore, you never know when a pi**ed off drunkard grabs an axe… Maybe that drunkard just barely went to school in the 1950-1960’s and can never understand that the mockumentary is mocking stereotypes on all sides, he just got drunk because all he is feeling is being humiliated, the alcohol only enhances that feeling and the rest is just falling dominoes… I heard that there was a lawsuit about this and that it was dismissed in court. Anyway, I don’t think Sasha Cohen wanted to record a snuff video in some Romanian village for Pink Floyd - “Careful with that axe, Eugene”, although it would have been interesting to see Sasha Cohen running in circles in a muddy courtyard making high pitched screams while not getting out of the character, the “ultimate” actor test, the final hit vs. “the final hit”… I’m sure the movie didn’t have its final name until they went to that village, I’m sure the villagers thought he was mocking them so they started calling him names, one of those names being “borât” (meaning “puked” which is a very nasty equivalent of “a**hole” and “stuff” like that, even nastier, and that is why there is an exclamation mark after the name on the movie poster). In order to give it an even more “sovieto-exotic” look, “â” was changed with “Д” (which is actually “D/d”)… It was meant for the “western” viewer so it doesn’t matter if it’s “â” or “d”, but it has to have the “sovieto-exotic” look of “Д” which the “western” viewer stereotypically expects and then the character reads it as “A” because he is not used to pronounce “Â” and neither the viewer, case closed. (For who is really curious, that vowel is this: Close central unrounded vowel - Wikipedia There is a sound sample there but it doesn’t sound 100% how it’s supposed to be, that sound sample sounds more like this Moo box - Wikipedia because it’s out of the context of a word and I don’t think the recorder knew Romanian, just general phonetics in theory…) So it doesn’t matter if it’s Romanian or if it’s Kazakh, the producers just needed to have a certain look/sound to fit in the “sovieto-exotic” stereotype of the “western” viewer’s cultural perspective for as cheap as possible. (Maybe “cultural” and “perspective” should be also placed in quotation marks, idk, you get the point…) Anyway…, when you watch the movie “BORДT!”, you are actually watching the movie “A**HOLE!” or some similar name, go get popcorn! Good luck! EDIT: i remembered something… The main character is being asked by the “father” (who doesn’t ask as a character, that Roma is visibly in no character at all, he is not acting): “Ț’-am făcut curat, îț’ place?” (“We cleaned up, you like it?”) The “space” that was chosen as the main character’s bedroom didn’t have in the beginning the purpose of a bedroom, it was some sort of deposit room, one can see that it has a fresh paint with Copper(II) sulfate - Wikipedia, a bit diluted. He really got them angry by refusing the guest room and getting them to fake the deposit room as a bed room, it’s seen as very disrespectful.

The movie is intended to be a comedy based loosely upon a fake documentary. The written language seen in the movie is faked by reversing letters or using symbolic Cyrillic script, mixed with western script. The languages used are variously Romanian, Armenian, Hebrew, and fraudulent heavily accented English etc.
